overall_score_comment: It's like a fortune cookie wrote a diss track — sounds profound until you realize you've read the same thing twelve times.
the_roast:
Let's start with the elephant in the room: Doja sampled Dionne Warwick's 'Walk On By' and then proceeded to walk ON by any semblance of lyrical variety. 'She the devil, she a bad lil' bitch, she a rebel' gets repeated so many times, I'm pretty sure it qualifies as a meditation mantra at this point. If I wanted this much repetition, I'd just hit my head against a wall while listening to a car alarm.

The anatomical geography lesson in 'I put good dick all in my kidneys' is sending medical students into crisis mode. Ma'am, that's not how kidneys work, and if it IS, you need a doctor, not a record deal. Meanwhile, 'My illness don't come with no remedy' followed immediately by 'I am so much fun without Hennessy' is giving us whiplash faster than a neck injury lawyer convention. Are we bragging about being sick or about sobriety? Pick a lane!

The self-awareness is simultaneously the song's best and worst quality. 'I'd rather be famous instead' and 'I let all that get to my head' — okay, we appreciate the honesty, but repeating it eight times doesn't make it deeper, it makes it a ringtone. And 'Fame ain't somethin' that I need no more' at the END of a song literally titled 'Paint the Town Red' about wanting to be famous is the kind of plot twist M. Night Shyamalan would reject for being too contradictory. It's like ordering a supersized Big Mac meal and then announcing you're not really hungry.

The whole 'devil/rebel/pedal/settle' rhyme scheme is working harder than a one-legged man in a butt-kicking contest, showing up in every single chorus like that one friend who doesn't know when the party's over. And 'You gon' see me eatin' ten more times' — is that a threat or a Mukbang channel announcement? I genuinely can't tell if we're being intimidated or invited to brunch.

cliche_counter.cliche: Calling herself 'the devil' and a 'bad bitch'
cliche_counter.quip: Edgy teenager core, except the teenager has a Vegas residency

cliche_counter.cliche: The 'I don't care' attitude repeated ad nauseam
cliche_counter.quip: If you truly didn't care, you wouldn't need to tell us 47 times
Every rapper since 2003 called, they want their gas pedal back
Groundbreaking stuff — next you'll tell us you like expensive things
Nothing says 'I'm unbothered' like writing an entire song about being bothered

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I put good dick all in my kidneys
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Crimes against anatomy and basic human biology
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory retake of 9th grade health class

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Said my happiness is all of your misery
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Trying to pass off sadism as a personality trait
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Required to watch every feel-good Pixar movie until empathy develops

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: She the devil / She a bad lil' bitch, she a rebel
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Rhyming a word with itself and calling it a day (x6 counts)
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Write 'I will not be lazy with rhymes' 500 times on a chalkboard

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Fall off what? I ain't seen the horse
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Mixing metaphors so badly the horse filed for divorce
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Banned from using idioms without adult supervision

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I'd rather be famous instead... Fame ain't somethin' that I need no more
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Contradiction so blatant it should come with a disclaimer
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must attend a workshop on commitment and follow-through

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is an avant-garde commentary on the cyclical nature of fame and the repetitive structure mirrors the endless hamster wheel of celebrity culture. Or, and hear me out, someone discovered the copy-paste function and got a little too excited. The Dionne Warwick sample is basically the song begging us to 'walk on by' and pretend we didn't hear it, which is honestly the most honest part of the whole track.
final_verdict: It's a bop with the lyrical depth of a kiddie pool — fun to splash around in, but don't expect to dive deep. Doja said what she said, and then said it again, and again, and we GET IT.
title: Paint the Town Red
